bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, June 4, 1901
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

p.add: ack. by form & to Hon. C. E. Littlefield July 17-1901 go peroon ack

div1.p: No. 73. Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, June 4, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. The claim of Miss Winfred Miller, against F. O. Thorne Esq. of Liberia; for $456.59, is now secured by the Liberian Government.

Synopsis. The Honorable F. O. Thorne, has given me an order on Hon. Arthur Carclay, Secretary of the Treasury Liberian Government, for $456.59, in "Government Bills," in settlement of the claim of Miss Winfred Miller.
No. 73. Consular. Legation of the United States Monrovia Liberia, June 4, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Seretary of State, Washington.

Sir: Refering to my No. 62, Consular of February 9, 1901, I have the honor to say that I secured an order, from Hon. F. O. Thorne, May 30, 1901; on the Honorable Arthur Barclay, Secretary of the Treasury, for Four Hundred, Fifty-six 59/100 Dollars, in audited Government Bills, in settlement of the claim of Miss Winfred Miller, of New Castle Maine. I had been previously informed by the President that he had advised Secretary Barclay to accept the order, in
in fact, the order had been accepted, by him, before it was presented to me. The Government has now assumed the debt and promises to pay same soon.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General.
